DOCNAME: ADZI-SPIRKOSKA AND OTHERS v. "THE FORMER YUGOSLAV REPUBLIC OF MACEDONIA"
JUDGES: Anatoly Kovler;Erik Møse;Julia Laffranque;Khanlar Hajiyev;Linos-Alexandre Sicilianos;Mirjana Lazarova Trajkovska
TEXT: The applicants , PERSON ( “ the first applicant ” ) , PERSON Straso Gorgieski ( “ the second applicant ” ) , PERSON FAC ( “ the third applicant ” ) , PERSON ( “ the fourth applicant ” ) and PERSON PERSON PERSON ( “ the fifth applicant ” ) , are NORP nationals who were born in DATE , DATE , DATE , DATE and DATE respectively and live in NORP and GPE . The third and fourth applicants died on DATE and CARDINAL DATE respectively . PERSON , the daughter of the third applicant , and PERSON and PERSON , the daughters of the fourth applicant , have applied to continue the application in the name of their predecessors and designated the same counsel to represent them . For the sake of convenience , they will be referred to as “ the successors of the third and fourth applicants ” . The first applicant , a qualified lawyer from NORP , was granted leave to represent the second , third and fourth applicants . The fifth applicant was represented by Mr PERSON , a practising lawyer from GPE . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , PERSON .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

In DATE the confiscation commission of the city of GPE , the body with authority at the time , confiscated CARDINAL plots of undeveloped building land from the ORG late predecessors in order to construct residential buildings .

On DATE the first , second , third and fourth applicants instituted restitution proceedings in which they sought restoration of title to the land that remained undeveloped and compensation in return for the remainder . CARDINAL decisions have been given so far , including CARDINAL decisions by ORG on appeals on points of law ( тужба за управен спор ) by the applicants . The most recent decision was given on DATE , when the restitution commission accepted the ORG claim and awarded compensation in return for the confiscated land . The applicants challenged this decision before ORG . The proceedings are still pending .

In DATE the fifth applicant brought a civil action against his former employer , seeking compensation for injuries sustained while at work . In DATE ORG , deciding upon appeals on points of law , ruled partly in favour of the applicant and awarded him compensation for the non - pecuniary loss sustained . The proceedings are still pending before ORG in respect of the applicant ’s claim for pecuniary damage ( “ the compensation proceedings ” ) .

On DATE the fifth applicant requested ORG to find a violation of the “ reasonable time ” requirement in respect of the compensation proceedings and to award just satisfaction . On DATE ORG found that the compensation proceedings had lasted too long and that they had not yet ended . It set a DATE time - limit for ORG to decide on the applicant ’s claim on the merits . It also awarded him compensation in the amount of MONEY ( ORG – equivalent to MONEY ( ORG ) ) as just satisfaction for the violation found . It further reimbursed the costs and expenses incurred in the course of these proceedings . The fifth applicant did not appeal against the decision . It became final on DATE . The amount awarded was paid to the fifth applicant .

Under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(CARDINAL ) of LAW , ORG is competent to decide on appeals against decisions of its panels when so specified by law . Under section CARDINAL ) , ORG is competent to decide on length complaints in proceedings specified by law .

Section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act provided that an interested party could apply to the immediately higher court ( непосредно повисокиот суд ) if he or she considered that there had been a breach by a competent court of the right to a hearing within a reasonable time . The immediately higher court was to deal with the length complaint ( постапува по барањето ) within DATE after the application had been lodged and to decide whether the court below had breached the right in question . The higher court would award just satisfaction to the claimant if it found a violation of the right to a hearing within a reasonable time . The just satisfaction was payable from the court ’s budget .
LAW became applicable on DATE ( section CARDINAL ) .
Section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act supplements section NORP ) of LAW , and provides that ORG is to decide in accordance with the rules and principles specified in LAW and the ORG ’s case - law .

Section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act amends section CARDINAL of LAW , providing for the exclusive competence of ORG to determine length - of - proceedings cases . The relevant part of this section reads as follows :
“ An interested party can use the length remedy while proceedings are pending , but not DATE after the decision becomes final .
The length complaint shall contain :
- information about the claimant and his or her representative ,
- information about the case and proceedings complained of ,
- an indication of the reasons for the alleged violation of the right to a hearing within a reasonable time ,
- any claim for just satisfaction and
- the signature of the claimant .

The ORG shall consider a length complaint meeting the criteria specified in subsections ( CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) within DATE after it has been lodged and shall decide whether the court below breached the right to a hearing within a reasonable time . In so doing , it shall take into consideration the rules and principles set forth in ORG , in particular the complexity of the case , the parties’ behaviour and the conduct of the court in question .

If ORG finds a violation of the right to a hearing within a reasonable time , it may set a time - limit for the court before which the impugned proceedings are pending to determine the right , obligation or criminal responsibility of the claimant and award just satisfaction for the violation found .
Just satisfaction is to be paid within DATE after ORG decision becomes final . ”
Section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act adds a new section CARDINAL-a , which reads as follows :

“ After receiving the length complaint , ORG shall immediately , or within DATE at the latest , request the first - instance court to forward the case file to it , and if need be , request the higher court to indicate the reasons for the length of the proceedings pending before it .

A CARDINAL - judge panel of ORG , sitting in private , shall decide on the length remedy . In exceptional cases , ORG may hear representations from the claimant and from the representative of the court concerned .
Within DATE after receipt , the party concerned may appeal against the panel ’s decision before ORG , which shall decide in accordance with section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(CARDINAL ) . ”
LAW entered into force DATE after being published in ORG ( section CARDINAL ) .

Section CARDINAL of this Act adds a new section CARDINAL-b , by which ORG must forward a copy of its decision , DATE after its adoption , to ORG . The latter must request the claimant , within DATE at the latest , to submit personal bank account details with a view to receiving payment of the just satisfaction awarded by ORG . If the claimant does not submit the required information within DATE , the amount awarded is to be deposited in a special account of ORG . It is to be transferred to the claimant ’s bank account once the latter has submitted the required information . If the claimant does not submit the relevant account details within DATE after the amount was deposited with ORG , the money is to be returned to the ORG ’s budget .

The ORG budget is an DATE assessment of the assets and liabilities of the judiciary and the ORG for training of judges and public prosecutors ( “ the ORG ” – section CARDINAL ) . The ORG budget is managed by ORG ( section CARDINAL ) . The latter is chaired by the President of ORG . It is further composed of the Minister of ORG , the Presidents of ORG , ORG and CARDINAL courts of first instance and the Director of the ORG ( section CARDINAL ) .

In view of the ORG ’s decision in GPE and Others v. the former GPE ( ( dec . ) , no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , CARDINAL DATE ) , the “ length - of - proceedings ” department of ORG adopted the following recommendations :
a ) expedite proceedings before ORG in length - of - proceedings cases and keep their length DATE , as specified in the CARDINAL Act ;
b ) award just satisfaction in an amount corresponding to the violation found , so that the claimant loses victim status ;
c ) organise ORG in such a way that it fully applies the ORG ’s case - law ;

d ) comply fully with the ORG ’s case - law as regards the amounts awarded by way of just satisfaction in length cases ; in this connection ORG established that the award should not be PERCENT of the sum awarded by ORG in similar cases ; and

e ) comply fully with the orders issued by ORG in cases in which it finds a violation of the “ reasonable time ” requirement , namely payment of just satisfaction and observance of the time - limit that it sets for the courts in question to determine the case on the merits .

According to statistics produced by ORG in DATE , CARDINAL length - of - proceedings cases have been brought before that court since the CARDINAL Act entered into force . The court has examined CARDINAL cases , including CARDINAL in DATE , CARDINAL in DATE , CARDINAL in DATE and CARDINAL until DATE .

A violation of the “ reasonable time ” requirement has been found in CARDINAL cases , including CARDINAL cases in DATE , CARDINAL cases in DATE and CARDINAL in DATE . Since DATE , CARDINAL cases have been decided to the claimants’ significant advantage . These cases have concerned the length of civil , criminal , minor - offence , administrative , insolvency and enforcement proceedings . Decisions on the merits dismissing length complaints have been rendered in CARDINAL cases . ORG has further rejected CARDINAL length cases as failing to comply with the admissibility requirements .

Appeal proceedings have been instituted in CARDINAL cases . The second - instance panel of ORG has given a decision in nearly all those cases . It has allowed the appeals and awarded compensation in a higher amount than that awarded at first instance in CARDINAL cases ; it has dismissed appeals in CARDINAL cases and rejected them in CARDINAL cases .

In CARDINAL cases the length of proceedings before ORG relating to the length remedy has been DATE ; in CARDINAL cases , the proceedings have lasted DATE ; in CARDINAL cases , they have lasted DATE , in CARDINAL cases DATE and in CARDINAL cases DATE . In CARDINAL of the CARDINAL cases decided so far in DATE , the proceedings before ORG have lasted DATE and in CARDINAL cases they have lasted not DATE .

ORG has awarded just satisfaction in CARDINAL cases . The total amount awarded in these cases is equivalent to ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL . Since DATE , the court has awarded compensation in CARDINAL cases , the total amount of which is approximately EUR CARDINAL . Of the total amount awarded , EUR CARDINAL,CARDINAL has so far been paid to the claimants . In CARDINAL cases the compensation was paid within DATE from the date on which ORG decision awarding compensation had become final ; in CARDINAL cases the award was paid with a delay of DATE ( in CARDINAL cases the delay was attributable to the ORG ) ; in CARDINAL cases the payment was made with a delay of DATE ; in CARDINAL cases there was a DATE delay ; in CARDINAL cases the payment was made with a DATE delay and lastly , in CARDINAL cases the award was paid with a delay of DATE . In CARDINAL cases the delay was attributable to the claimants .

Finally , in CARDINAL cases , CARDINAL of which were decided in DATE , ORG has also set a deadline of DATE for the courts in question to determine the parties’ claims in the substantive proceedings . In CARDINAL cases the courts concerned have complied with ORG order .
